courseDescription: Elementary financial accounting concepts and procedures used in the preparation of financial statements; elementary financial statement analysis; and use of financial accounting information for special-purpose decision making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of financial accounting information for decision making
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on financial reporting

courseDescription: Elementary managerial accounting concepts and procedures; operational accounting; and use of accounting data for special-purpose internal decision making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of accounting software for decision making
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of financial information to non-accounting personnel
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting accounting data for decision-making purposes

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College. Special honors section of ACCT 201.  Elementary financial accounting concepts and procedures used in the preparation of financial statements; elementary financial statement analysis; and use of financial accounting information for special-purpose decision making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of financial accounting information for decision making
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making based on financial information

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  Special honors section of ACCT 202.  Elementary managerial accounting concepts and procedures; operational accounting; and use of accounting data for special-purpose internal decision making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of accounting data for decision making
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in analyzing accounting data

courseDescription: This course is for non-accounting students who wish to start their own businesses. The course is designed to support entrepreneur activities such as: producing meaningful financial statements and management accounting reports to measure firm performance; choosing the appropriate business entity type; basic tax issues and planning in starting and running a small business; establishing an effective governance structure; and setting up an anti-fraud prevention program. Accounting majors or minors cannot use this course as an accounting elective, but can use the course as a 300-400 business elective. This course will not be used in the calculation of grade point average for an accounting major or accounting minor.

This course is required for students following the accounting curriculum in the 2015-16, 2016-17, 2017-18, and 2018-19 Catalogs and should be taken only by these students.  The course covers financial statement and managerial accounting information preparation for external and internal users in accordance with prevailing accounting standards established by recognized accounting bodies. Students who have not had ACCT 201 and ACCT 202 within two years of planning to enroll in ACCT 301 are strongly encouraged to retake these courses in preparation for ACCT 301.  Students must have a C or better in ACCT 301 to proceed to other upper-level accounting courses. Students in the Accounting Major Professional (AP) program or seeking acceptance in the MSA program must achieve a B- or better in ACCT 301.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recognized accounting bodies' standards
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with external and internal users
Presentation of financial information to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of accounting standards to real-world scenarios
Identification of discrepancies in financial statements

courseDescription: This course is required for students following the accounting curriculum in the 2015-16, 2016-17, 2017-18, and 2018-19 Catalogs and should be taken only by these students.  Preparation of financial statements and other reports in accordance with prevailing accounting standards established by the accounting profession. Students must have a C- or better grade in ACCT 302 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students in the Accounting Major Professional concentration or seeking admission to the MSA program must earn a grade of B- or better.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on financial reports
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritizing tasks in financial statement preparation

courseDescription: This course is the gateway to the undergraduate accounting program at Old Dominion University. It is the first of three financial accounting courses designed to strengthen the technical, communication, and critical thinking skills required to succeed in accounting-related careers. This course covers the theoretical foundation, concepts, and principles that underlie financial statement preparation. It exposes students to accounting by providing an in-depth study of the accounting cycle, income statement and balance sheet. Students gain an understanding of how financial statements are prepared using Excel, including an introduction to data analysis using Excel and authoritative sources to support an accounting position. Students who have not had ACCT 201 and ACCT 202 within two years of planning to enroll in ACCT 305 are strongly encouraged to retake these courses in preparation for ACCT 305. Students must have a C or better in ACCT 305 to proceed to other upper-level accounting courses. Students seeking acceptance to the MSA program must achieve a B- or better in ACCT 305.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using authoritative sources for accounting positions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Achieving required grades for MSA program acceptance

courseDescription: This is the second of the three-course financial accounting series and continues the study of financial statement preparation. Selected topics include: inventories; property, plant, and equipment; investments; and current and long-term liabilities. Students gain an in-depth understanding of how these topics are presented in the financial statements and use the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to support an accounting position. Students gain an understanding of how financial statements are prepared using Excel, including an introduction to data analysis using Excel and authoritative sources to support an accounting position. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 306 to proceed to other upper-level accounting courses. Students seeking acceptance to the MSA program must achieve a B- or better in ACCT 306.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of inventories, investments, and liabilities in financial statements

courseDescription: This is the third of the three-course financial accounting series and continues the study of financial statement preparation. Selected topics include leases, pensions, accounting for income taxes, stockholders’ equity, earnings per share, the Statement of Cash Flows, and other corporate reporting issues. Students gain an in-depth understanding of how these topics are presented in the financial statements and use the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to support an accounting position Students gain an understanding of how financial statements are prepared using Excel, including an introduction to data analysis using Excel and authoritative sources to support an accounting position. Students must have a C- or better grade in ACCT 307 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students seeking admission to the MSA program must earn a grade of B- or better in ACCT 307.

This course is required for students following the accounting curriculum in the 2015-16, 2016-17, 2017-18, and 2018-19 Catalogs and should be taken only by these students. This course focuses on recording and allocating costs within traditional managerial accounting systems. Common and joint cost allocations are performed under job order, process and standard costing systems. Income models are developed for exploring cost-volume-profit relationships. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 311 to graduate with a major in accounting.  Students in the Accounting Major Professional concentration or seeking admission to the MSA program must earn a grade of B- or better.
Technical and Digital Skills: Cost allocation methods in managerial accounting

courseDescription: May be repeated for credit and available for pass/fail grading only. Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of work experience criteria
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning work experience activities, coordinating with Career Development Services

courseDescription: Student participation in a professional work experience. Approval for enrollment and allowable credits are determined by the department and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Professional work experience in a specific field
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with supervisors and colleagues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new challenges in a professional setting
Identifying and addressing issues in work tasks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a work environment
Working collaboratively in a team setting

courseDescription: Student participation in a professional work experience. Approval for enrollment and allowable credits are determined by the department CAP adviser and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Professional work experience in a specialized field

courseTitle: Accounting and Auditing in the Public/Nonprofit Sector
courseDescription: The application of accounting principles to governmental funds and not-for-profit organizations.  Emphasis is placed on budgeting and control as well as auditing concerns for such entities. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 405 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students in the Accounting Major Professional concentration or seeking acceptance to the MSA program must achieve a B- or better in ACCT 405.
Technical and Digital Skills: Governmental and nonprofit accounting principles application
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of financial information to stakeholders
Collaboration with team members on auditing concerns
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing budgeting variances in governmental and nonprofit organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading auditing teams in governmental and nonprofit settings
Managing budgeting processes in such entities

courseDescription: Current financial auditing processes are emphasized, and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) are used to evaluate the fairness of financial statements. Additionally, standards and ethics of the public accounting profession, generally accepted auditing standards, and public reporting are covered.  Students must have a C- or better grade in ACCT 411 to graduate with a major in accounting.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Root cause analysis of financial discrepancies

courseDescription: An intensive course in taxation. Focuses on the choice of business entity by covering taxation of corporations (both C and S corporations), partnerships and sole proprietorships.  The course emphasizes research skills and professional ethics. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 422 to graduate with a major in accounting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Financial statement analysis for tax purposes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with tax professionals and clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of tax laws and regulations
Identification of tax implications for different business entities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing tax data for efficient analysis

courseDescription: An analysis of federal income tax law and its application to personal and business tax situations. Reconciliation of tax and accounting concepts. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 425 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students seeking admission to the MSA program must earn a grade of B- or better. This course, plus an additional self-study module and test on Blackboard, will satisfy the requirement for those whose catalog requires ACCT 421.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of personal and business tax situations
Leadership in tax planning and compliance

courseDescription: An analysis of federal income tax law and its application to business entities. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 426 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students seeking admission to the MSA program must earn a grade of B- or better.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of tax law to business entities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of tax implications to stakeholders
Collaboration with tax professionals and business leaders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing complex tax scenarios for businesses
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing tax compliance for business entities
Leading tax strategy development for organizations

courseDescription: The study of accounting for international operations and business combinations. Students may enroll in ACCT 450 as the BSBA required International Business elective.  Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 450 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students in the Accounting Major Professional concentration or seeking acceptance to the MSA program must achieve a B- or better in ACCT 450.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of complex international financial data
Identification of accounting issues in global business operations

courseDescription: The theoretical and practical approaches to the understanding of accounting information systems. Emphasis is placed on the understanding of how accounting is related to other business processes, how internal controls are ensured, and exposure to manual and ERP based accounting systems. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 460 to graduate with a major in accounting. Students are encouraged to take ACCT 460 before completing ACCT 411.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ERP based accounting systems

courseDescription: Study designed for students desiring additional work in an area of particular interest in accounting.  This course may not be substituted for any required accounting course. Students must have a C- or better in ACCT 495 to graduate.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing spreadsheet functions for financial analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration on accounting projects with team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for complex accounting problems

courseTitle: Accounting and Auditing in the Public/Nonprofit Sector
courseDescription: The application of accounting principles to governmental funds and not-for-profit organizations.  Emphasis is placed on budgeting and control as well as auditing concerns for such entities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear reporting to stakeholders in the nonprofit sector
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Budget analysis and forecasting for governmental funds
Identifying control weaknesses in nonprofit organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading audit teams in the public sector
Project management for auditing concerns in nonprofits

courseDescription: Current financial auditing processes are emphasized, and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) are used to evaluate the fairness of financial statements. Additionally, standards and ethics of the public accounting profession, generally accepted auditing standards, and public reporting are covered.
An analysis of federal income tax law and its application to personal and business tax situations.  Reconciliation of tax and accounting concepts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying tax law to personal and business situations
Reconciliation of tax and accounting concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders regarding tax situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying tax implications in different situations

courseDescription: An intensive course in taxation. Focuses on the choice of business entity by covering taxation of corporations (both C and S corporations), partnerships and sole proprietorships. The course emphasizes research skills and professional ethics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Taxation of corporations (C and S corporations)
Taxation of partnerships and sole proprietorships

courseDescription: The study of accounting for international operations and business combinations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Consolidation of financial statements for global entities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex financial information to diverse stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing foreign exchange impact on financial statements
Interpreting international tax implications on business operations

courseDescription: A study of concepts of managerial accounting.  This course focuses on the techniques and approaches to organizing and understanding internally generated accounting information.  The objective of the course is to provide students with a set of tools that utilize managerial accounting information for solving business problems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with cross-functional teams on cost analysis projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting internal accounting information for strategic planning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing performance measurement systems for team evaluation

courseDescription: A study of the concepts of financial accounting.  This course covers the financial reporting process and the development of financial statements for external users.  The overall objective of the course is to provide students with a sufficient fluency to be intelligent readers of financial accounting information.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of financial data to external users
Collaboration with stakeholders on financial reporting
Presentation of financial information in a clear and concise manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of financial data for decision-making
Identification of financial trends and patterns
Interpretation of financial statements for strategic planning

courseDescription: Accounting analytics appropriate for professional accountants, whether in public accounting, industry, or government/non-profit. Much of the course involves hands-on learning focusing on decision, descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive analytics using the latest analytics/data visualization software.
Standards, ethics, and practice of information technology assurance services particularly as it concerns the governance and control of information systems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of technical findings to non-technical stakeholders
Collaboration with cross-functional teams on audit projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and remediation of control weaknesses
Root cause analysis of security incidents
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of IT assurance engagements
Team leadership in audit planning and execution

courseDescription: Standards, ethics, and practice of fraud examination and forensic accounting particularly as it concerns the accounting profession.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis tools for financial investigations

courseDescription: This course covers current financial accounting standards and the problems faced by national and multinational corporations in reporting financial information to external users in a global economy. There will be a discussion of the various techniques for presenting and analyzing financial statements and the ethical issues related to those presentations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of financial information to external users
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and resolving reporting challenges faced by corporations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for financial statement presentations

courseDescription: Covers cost concepts and analysis in both a manufacturing and service operational environment.  Provides an introduction to activity based costing and standard cost systems, methodology for measuring productivity changes and cost of quality and measurement and control of operating performance.

courseTitle: Business Valuations using Financial Statement Analysis
courseDescription: This course covers the analysis and interpretation of financial statements, including the significant accounting issues involved in performing an effective valuation of a company.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on valuation projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key financial metrics for valuation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading valuation team discussions and decision-making

courseTitle: Professional Ethics and Legal Issues In Accounting
courseDescription: An intensive course covering ethical and legal issues confronted by practicing accountants.  The course emphasizes rigorous analysis of complex situations leading to appropriate solutions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of financial data analysis tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex accounting issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical and legal dilemmas in accounting
Analytical reasoning for complex accounting situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in resolving legal issues in accounting

courseDescription: An intensive course in taxation. Focuses on the choice of business entity by covering taxation of corporations (both C and S corporations), partnerships and sole proprietor-ships. The course emphasizes research skills and professional ethics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of C and S corporations taxation
Partnerships and sole proprietorships tax implications awareness
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with tax professionals and clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of tax implications for business decisions
Research skills for tax planning strategies
Evaluation of tax efficiency for different business entities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of tax documents and filings

courseDescription: Covers federal income taxation of corporations and shareholders. Includes organizing a corporation; establishing capital structure; determining tax liability; dividends and other non-liquidating distributions; stock redemptions; and liquidations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding federal income taxation laws for corporations
Analyzing capital structure for tax optimization
Interpreting tax implications of dividends and distributions
Knowledge of stock redemptions and liquidations in tax context
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex tax concepts to stakeholders
Collaborating with tax professionals and shareholders
Negotiating tax strategies with clients or authorities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing financial data for tax planning purposes
Interpreting tax laws for specific corporate scenarios
Evaluating tax consequences of different corporate actions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading tax planning initiatives for corporations
Coordinating with legal and financial teams for tax compliance
Managing tax documentation and reporting processes

courseDescription: Taxation of partners and partnerships: formation, termination, distributions and liquidations, and sales of partnership interests. Limited partnerships in conjunction with their use as tax shelters, and the multifaceted attributes of family partnerships.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding tax laws related to partnerships
Analyzing tax implications of partnership transactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating tax consequences of partnership decisions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading tax planning initiatives for partnerships

courseDescription: Examines transfers under federal estate and gift tax laws. Includes property owned by the decedent; retained life estates; transfers taking effect at death; transfers with retained powers; concurrent property interest; powers of appointment; valuation problems; expenses, debts, and taxes; charitable bequests; marital deduction; taxable inter vivos gifts; gift splitting and credits; consideration of Chapter 14 and asset freezing techniques; and transfer taxation of life insurance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Valuation techniques for estate and gift tax purposes
Understanding federal estate and gift tax laws
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex tax concepts to clients
Negotiating with tax authorities on estate and gift tax matters
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing concurrent property interests for tax implications
Identifying and resolving valuation problems in estate and gift tax calculations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading estate planning meetings with clients
Managing multiple estate and gift tax cases simultaneously

courseTitle: Income Taxation of Estates, Trusts & Beneficiaries
courseDescription: Examines simple, complex, and revocable trusts; trusts accumulation distributions; income in respect of decedents; trust accounting income; distributable net income; terminations; excess deductions; basis rules; and the decedent's final income tax return.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of income tax laws related to estates and trusts
Knowledge of distributable net income rules
Ability to prepare the decedent's final income tax return
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with beneficiaries and trustees regarding tax implications
Ability to explain complex tax concepts to non-tax professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving issues related to excess deductions
Interpreting basis rules for estate and trust assets
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Providing leadership in coordinating estate tax filings

courseDescription: Analyzes the different types of taxable and tax-free acquisitions and reorganizations. Includes determining tax consequences for corporations and shareholders involved in an acquisition or reorganization and analyzing necessary requirements for a tax-free corporate division (spin-off). Covers aspects of filing consolidated federal income tax returns.
Technical and Digital Skills: Tax consequences analysis for corporations and shareholders
Filing consolidated federal income tax returns
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of tax implications to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of tax consequences in acquisitions and reorganizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for tax-free corporate divisions (spin-offs)

courseDescription: Discusses federal income taxation of deferred compensation plans with emphasis on qualified retirement plans. Reviews plan qualification requirements, reporting and disclosure requirements, and distribution rules. Includes discussion of specific types of plans such as Sec. 401(K) and ESOPs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding federal income tax laws related to deferred compensation plans
Knowledge of qualified retirement plans regulations
Familiarity with reporting and disclosure requirements for deferred compensation
Understanding distribution rules for deferred compensation plans
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex tax concepts to clients or colleagues
Interacting with plan participants to explain tax implications
Communicating effectively with IRS or other regulatory bodies regarding plan compliance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the tax implications of different types of deferred compensation plans
Identifying potential issues with plan qualification requirements
Resolving discrepancies in plan reporting and disclosures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in ensuring plan compliance with tax laws
Organizing and overseeing the implementation of new deferred compensation plans
Managing multiple deadlines related to plan qualification and reporting

courseTitle: Taxation of the Small Business Corporation
courseDescription: Covers federal income taxation of S corporations including election eligibility; termination of status; treatment of income and deduction items; distributions; and basis of stock and debt. Also discusses compensation arrangements in closely held corporations; fiscal year issues; personal service corporations; the advantages of C corporations versus S corporations; corporation liquidation and redemption rules; and the S corporations' built-in gains tax.
Technical and Digital Skills: Basis of stock and debt calculation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients on tax matters
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing income and deduction items for tax optimization
Identifying built-in gains for tax planning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on advantages of C corporations vs. S corporations

courseDescription: Discusses procedures for dealing with the IRS. Includes sources of IRS policy; processing returns; auditing returns; rulings and determination letters; assessments and collections; and interest and civil penalties.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of tax laws and regulations
Familiarity with rulings and determination letters
Calculating interest and civil penalties correctly
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining tax procedures to clients clearly
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in tax procedures and practice
Coordinating with tax professionals and clients

courseDescription: Student participation in a full-time professional work experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Professional work experience in a specific field
Hands-on application of technical knowledge in real-world settings
Troubleshooting technical issues in a professional environment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with colleagues and supervisors
Networking with professionals in the field
Providing updates on progress and results to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing challenges in the workplace
Analyzing data or information to make informed decisions
Adapting to changing circumstances or requirements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively in a professional setting
Taking initiative on tasks or projects
Leading a team towards common goals
Demonstrating accountability and responsibility in work tasks

courseDescription: The course is a practicum in the profession of accounting where theories, concepts, and financial management techniques are applied in a business environment.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective written and verbal communication with clients and team members
Ability to explain complex financial concepts clearly
Active listening skills during client meetings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing financial data to identify trends and patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in completing assigned projects
Working collaboratively in a team setting

courseDescription: Study designed for students who have had one of the required courses waived or for students desiring additional work in an area of particular interest in accounting.
Individually supervised research projects in selected tax areas. Approval of supervising professor as to topic and evaluation of project required at time of registration.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervision and evaluation of tax projects

courseDescription: This course focuses on advanced costing concepts, current management accounting practices, and analytical techniques employed by controllers in supporting their organizations' strategic planning processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analytical techniques for strategic planning processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategic decision-making based on cost analysis

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of the role of financial accounting in internal and external decision making. Financial modeling with an emphasis on assessing and valuing economic return will be included.

This course is the capstone course for the study of management accounting.  It includes a review of management accounting practices and analytical techniques employed by controllers in supporting their organization's strategic decision-making process.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading cross-functional teams in financial projects

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fall course for master's students in their final semester.  It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
